awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Efficient Secure Multiparty Computation of Large-Scale, Complex Protocols
awd_abstract_narration:
Many challenging real world problems, e.g., voting and blind auction, require computation over sensitive data supplied by multiple mutually-distrustful entities. Elegant cryptographic theories have been developed to solve these problems without relying on a mutually-trusted third party. Practitioners also built prototypes capable of securely computing set intersection, AES encryption, Hamming distance, etc. However, many other applications, such as data mining and running universal machines, are far more complex than what can be supported by the state-of-the-art techniques. This work studies new methods and platforms to enable large-scale, complex cryptographic protocols in more efficient ways. Software produced will be released as open-source projects to benefit future research in related areas. 

One part of this project explores new extensible approaches to accommodate multiple Secure Multiparty Computation (SMC) protocols and enable studying interesting combinations of them, including a new compiler to provide a higher-level abstraction for generating SMC protocols. The other part involves research into several new optimizations to improve the performance and scalability of SMC, through reuse of validated components to amortize validation costs. The educational activities of this project include mentoring both undergraduate and graduate students in applied cryptography research and developing a graduate course in applied cryptography.

For further information see the project web site at: http://smc-in-action.soic.indiana.edu
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits. Over the course of this project, we developed novel tools, techniques and applications of secure computation. Research papers from this proposal has been published at premium security conferences including IEEE Symposium on S&P [1], ACM CCS [2, 3, 4, 5], USENIX Security [6], ASIACRYPT [7], ESORICS [8], and has won Applied Security Research Best Paper Award (1st place) at CSAW’15. Four Ph.D students and nine undergraduate researchers were funded by this award and its REU supplements. 

Broader Impacts. Open-source software developed through this award includes ObliVM [9], CURIOUS [10], SPQ-EditDistance [11], Cut-and-Choose Game Solvers [12], nanoPI [13], POOL [14], and JIMU [15]. The PI's team has won the annual IDASH competitions in both 2015 and 2016 using the programming tools they developed for privacy-preserving genomics. This award supported the PI to file three US patents. Partly supported by this award, the PI has developed short course teaching materials (openly accessible on the PI's homepage) on MPC and taught at the Summer School on Secure and Oblivious Computation and Outsourcing at Notre Dame in 2016.

 

[1] C. Liu, X. S. Wang, K. Nayak, Y. Huang, and E. Shi. ObliVM: A programming framework for secure computation. In IEEE Symposium on Security and Privacy. 2015.

[2] V. Bindschaedler, M. Naveed, X. Pan, X. Wang, and Y. Huang. Practicing oblivious access on cloud storage: the gap, the fallacy, and the new way forward. In ACM CCS: 22nd Conference on Computer and Communications Security. 2015.

[3] X. S. Wang, Y. Huang, Y. Zhao, H. Tang, X. Wang, and D. Bu. Efficient genome-wide, privacy- preserving similar patient query based on private edit distance. In ACM CCS: 22nd Conference on Computer and Communications Security. 2015.

[4] R. Zhu, Y. Huang, and D. Cassel. Pool: Scalable on-demand secure computation service against malicious adversaries. In Proceedings of the 2017 ACM SIGSAC Conference on Computer and Communications Security, New York, NY, USA, 2017. ACM.

[5] R. Zhu, D. Cassel, A. Sabry, and Y. Huang. Nanopi: extreme-scale actively-secure multi-party com- putation. In Proceedings of the 2018 ACM SIGSAC Conference on Computer and Communications Security. ACM, 2018.

[6] R. Zhu, Y. Huang, A. Shelat, and J. Katz. The cut-and-choose game and its application to crypto- graphic protocols. In USENIX Security Symposium, 2016.

[7] R. Zhu and Y. Huang. JIMU: Faster lego-based secure computation using additive homomorphic hashes. In ASIACRYPT, 2017.

[8] D. Cassel, Y. Huang, and L. Jia. Uncovering information flow policy violations in c programs. In The 24th European Symposium on Research in Computer Security (ESORICS), 2019.

[9] ObliVM. https://github.com/ oblivm.

[10] Curious—a framework for oblivious cloud storage. http://seclab.soic.indiana.edu/curious/.

[11] Similar patient query through whole-genome edit distance. https:// github.com/SPQ-EditDistance.

[12] Better cut-and-choose params. https://github.com/Cut-N-Choose.

[13] NANOPI Extreme-Scale MPC Framework. https://github.com/ nanoPIMPC/nanoPI.

[14] Pool: A scalable and efficient maliciously secure computation framework. https://github.com/jimu-pool/PoolFramework.

[15] Jimu. https://github.com/jimu-pool/JIMU.


Last Modified: 08/26/2019
Modified by: Yan Huang
